title: Ticket #2249: back to back condor_hold + release can cause job removal
description:
Steps to repro:
  • get a series of long running sleep jobs to execute:
  • once your schedd is sufficiently busy run 2 times in a row"_condor_q && condor_hold -a && sleep 1 && condor_release -a && condor_q_"
  • watch your queue decrease in size.
remarks:
2011-Jun-16 15:27:34 by tstclair:
when looking through the Log you will notice a lot of

Job #.-1: not runnable

^^ then they are removed from the queue

2011-Jun-16 15:55:37 by jfrey:
I just reproduced with 30 running jobs. Only one of them left the queue during the second hold/release cycle. I see a lot of 'Job 253.-1: not runnable' in the schedd log, so I'm not convinced that's directly related to the problem. Also, the details look different than #1900. That is, the shadow isn't setting JobStatus to 6 (TRANSFERRING_OUTPUT) in the schedd just before exiting.

2011-Jun-16 16:46:17 by tstclair:
In tracing it looks to be a race condition on shutdown, because it appears that the shadows are cleaning up after the status has changed from the 2nd modification. Maybe there needs to be some additional logic here. 

case JOB_KILLED:
	// If the job isn't being HELD, we'll remove it
	if ( q_status != HELD ) {
	set_job_status( job_id.cluster, job_id.proc, REMOVED );
	}
break;

2011-Jun-17 09:28:35 by matt:
I'm able to reproduce by removing the "sleep 1" and running >30 jobs. Only the running jobs appear to be removed, which supports with Tim's theory.

This bug is possible from the beginning of time itself. A pain to track down due to numerous code reformattings. 

commit e36960755e96ac142669df746b95ed43a7111668
Author: wright <wright>
Date:   Thu Mar 15 21:48:08 2001 +0000

    Fixed bug for condor_hold on NT (and any using of the new shadow).  If
    the job we put on hold was running, we used to remove it from the
    queue.  Now, in child_exit(), we check the status of the job in the
    queue, and if it's HELD, we don't change the job status when the
    shadow exits w/ JOB_KILLED, JOB_COREDUMPED, etc.  This insures that
    check_zombie() won't remove the job from the queue.

commit 209f5873b9c08fe2d7ef7d837ff0f20b985deba9
Author: adiel <adiel>
Date:   Thu Feb 19 21:40:45 1998 +0000

    Jobs that are killed/coredumped are set to status REMOVED instead of COMPLETED

Before this the race would have show up as COMPLETED jobs, oops.

2011-Jun-17 10:06:22 by tstclair:
So making a simple switch to: 

case JOB_KILLED:
	// If the job isn't being HELD, we'll remove it
	if ( q_status != HELD && q_status != IDLE ) {
	set_job_status( job_id.cluster, job_id.proc, REMOVED );
	}
break;

fixes this particular issue, but I wonder if it handles all.

So the question would be:

Is there ever a case where the shadow exits 102, +JOB is marked as idle, and the job should be removed? Logic tells me it should be no.

2011-Jun-17 10:30:45 by matt:
Reproduced on... 

$CondorVersion: 7.0.2 Jun 12 2008 $
$CondorPlatform: X86_64-LINUX_RHEL5 $

With... 

Config: NUM_CPUS = 50
Submit: echo -e 'universe=vanilla\ncmd=/bin/sleep\nargs=1d\nqueue 100' | condor_submit <-- had to set the universe, wow!!
Running: condor_q | tail -n1 ; condor_hold -a ; condor_release -a ; condor_q | tail -n1 <-- after jobs start running, e.g.

$ condor_q | tail -n1 ; condor_hold -a ; condor_release -a ; condor_q | tail -n1
100 jobs; 50 idle, 50 running, 0 held
All jobs held.
All jobs released.
100 jobs; 100 idle, 0 running, 0 held
$ condor_q | tail -n1 ; condor_hold -a ; condor_release -a ; condor_q | tail -n1
50 jobs; 0 idle, 50 running, 0 held
All jobs held.
All jobs released.
50 jobs; 50 idle, 0 running, 0 held
